text:
Hi, 410 ppm represents 0.041 % of the atmosphere, not a 0.41% increase in co2. (also, notice the extra zero/decimal place). That is an increase from 0.028 % of the atmosphere (280 ppm) over approx. 270 years, (1750 - 2020), so an actual increase of 130 ppm, or an extra 0.013% of the atmosphere. 

0.041 % √∑ 0.028 % = a 46 % increase in co2 levels. ( not to be confused with 46 % of the atmosphere ). Add to that, the widely accepted, well known fact that increasing co2 gives diminishing returns. So, for example, a doubling of co2, ( or a 100 % increase in co2 levels ), will only result in approx. 1*C temp rise. So, even at 560 ppm, (2√ó 280 ppm), or 0.056 % of the atmosphere, temps would rise only 1*C. We have seen an approx. 1.4*C increase, over that 270 years, indicating there are (many) other factors at play.... Hope this helps. ; )

text:
¬†@Gary Ha¬† not to nit pick, but i believe you meant to say "an increase TO 0.041%... not an increase OF 0.041%.

Yes, alarmists love showing pictures of land surface ice breaking off into the ocean... as if that is some new phenomenon. The simple fact is it's all part of a much larger, and much more complicated system, and to some degree or another, it is being renewed continually. But they claim this "ancient" ice is "gone forever, never to return"... and yet the polar ice caps are still there.  And they always fail to mention the vast majority of sea ice is under the water's surface, out of view, thus making the sea ice look significantly less than it actually is. I generally ignore any and all close up shots, seeing as they can easily be taken out of context... the same way they love to bog us down with minute details, and charts, and figures... usually all taken out of their much broader context, in order to confuse the unsuspecting viewer. It's all quite pathetic, in my humble opinion.

I watched a video yesterday that first mentioned ice studies at the polar regions (plural), but then it focused only on the arctic ice cap shrinking, and conveniently failed to show the antarctic ice sheet, which was actually growing at the same time... very deceptive.

You raise an interesting question, though; one I had not considered. How do they know when there was no ice at the poles? What are the indicators?

text:
According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years.  That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago.  World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle.  The following is the source of this information:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de G√©ophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15¬∞C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Neftel, A., H. Oeschger, J. Schwander, B. Stauffer, and R. Zumbrunn. 1982. Ice core measurements give atmospheric CO2 content during the past 40,000 yr. Nature 295:220-23.

Pepin, L., D. Raynaud, J.-M. Barnola, and M.F. Loutre. 2001. Hemispheric roles of climate forcings during glacial-interglacial transitions as deduced from the Vostok record and LLN-2D model experiments. Journal of Geophysical Research 106 (D23): 31,885-31,892.

Petit, J.R., I. Basile, A. Leruyuet, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, J. Jouzel, M. Stievenard, V.Y. Lipenkov, N.I. Barkov, B.B. Kudryashov, M. Davis, E. Saltzman, and V. Kotlyakov. 1997. Four climate cycles in Vostok ice core. Nature 387: 359-360.

Petit, J.R., J. Jouzel, D. Raynaud, N.I. Barkov, J.-M. Barnola, I. Basile, M. Benders, J. Chappellaz, M. Davis, G. Delayque, M. Delmotte, V.M. Kotlyakov, M. Legrand, V.Y. Lipenkov, C. Lorius, L. P√©pin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

Raynaud, D., and J.-M. Barnola. 1985. An Antarctic ice core reveals atmospheric CO2 variations over the past few centuries. Nature 315:309-11.

CITE AS: Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, and N.I. Barkov. 2003. Historical CO2 record from the Vostok ice core. In Trends: A Compendium of Data on Global Change. Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

Revised February 2003

Yes, climate is changing but not necessarily due to man-made CO2 emissions. A modified theory of gravity allows periodic extra tidal energy to transport heat from the equator to the poles. This brings increased  precipitation which falls as snow. This accumulates into advancing glaciers. Glaciers are always melting but if the extra snowfall decreases then the glaciers retreat and the world enters an interglacial.

The snowfall of Antarctica has increased by 10% in the last 200 years which indicates the planet is slowly entering the 100,000-year cycle.

CO2 is a default mechanism from out-dated ice age theory. This is what Arrhenius based his research on and Greta bases her alarmism on.

¬†@Danny Scholten¬† Did you actually read it? He was in 1988 interviewed (not in writing!) what is the worst case scenario in 40 years. In roughly 2028.
"[...] to speculate on changes that might happen in New York City in 40 years assuming CO2 doubled in amount"
The climate change started with 280 ppm CO2. He was asked about 560 ppm.
Today we are at about 410.
If you would actually read the report (or the testimony) in 1988/89, he predicted 3 probable scenarios, depending on how much CO2 humans would produce, adding that the middle one was the most probable.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qL92L0tSGGI

Another point - according to the climate knowledge of that time of that time (1988), doubling the CO2 would rise the average temperature by 4,2¬∞C. Today with 30 years more data, the consensus is that the most probable value is 3¬∞C-
He wasn't lying or exaggerating, he was using the best knowledge of that time. And he was asked about the worst possible scenario.
And by the way, in 1988 the world was at 360 ppm. He was asked about 560 ppm - that's the amount we will reach (if nothing changes) in 2080-90, so the whole question was a false premise.

Once you quote a person, quote the whole statement, not one citation out of context.

text:
¬†@Timothy Scott¬† What you are doing is cherry-picking. Yes, the climate is changing, but not everywhere in the same way or in the same extent. Some regions will get dryer, others will have even more rain (and floods).

Looking further back? How about looking 140 year back, is this OK?
Until 1960 nothing much happened, the climate pretty much followed the amount of sunlight the Earth was getting from the Sun, give or take.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_activity_and_climate
But since then the temperatures are going ballistic.
Why? Well, the CO2 level in the previous centuries was fairly constant at about 280 ppm. In 1960 it was just closing in on 320 ppm. An increase, but not that dramatic yet.
Look at the recent levels. We are beyond 410.
https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/ccgg/trends/full.html
And this is why dr. Hansen focuses on the last few decades - because this is the timeframe where the current climate change went crazy.

text:
¬†@Andrew Johnston¬† For starters, there is not 0.01% extra co2. It is over 30% more than it has been for the past 10-15 million years and rising. We release 12000 tons of co2 every 10 seconds. We release over 8-9 gigatons per year, rising.Yes, excess amounts of co2 in the atmosphere are harmful, because they drive the temperature up, a process that is well understood, documenmted and proven.
What is also known is that, in the entire history of the earth, global temperature and co2 levels have always been related. When it was really hot on earth, co2 levels were really high and vice versa.
What is also known is that in the past 600000 years, there were several cold and hot periods, where temperatures shifted several degrees (parallel to co2 levels).
One such cycle from hot to cold lasted approximately 100000 years each time.

Now, we raised temperature by one degree in just 30-40 years. Scientists say our earth is warming 10-20 times faster than at any other point in time of earths history.
All of the things I just said are well documented and have been for years. I suggest reading scientific papers instead of facebook posts to form an opinion on the topic. Any more questions?

text:
Polar ice levels have varied on a cyclical basis for as long as data has been kept. And, based on other factors for hundreds of years. Ice extent in the Arctic has been almost unchanged over the last 6 years. Alarmists like to start all graphs and comparisons in 1979 because there was a historic high ice extent then. Even satellite data goes back to 1974, but that is harder to track down because ice levels were low then which indicated a cyclical
pattern. Look at the historical data, not the alarmist hype.

This body will be selected not elected, and there will be no mechanism to challenge their decisions. That would be a very bad thing IMO. Where do you sit Enzo?
author: Stuart Nicholson

text: ¬†@Stuart Nicholson¬† And would you put yourself down as a Labour supporter or a centrist Conservative? (I'm trying to understand the relationship between political stance, and opinions on climate change) Oh we are living it on the continent, very few would question climate change after the heatwave in early summer that broke many records, whether it's man-made, is another question. Either way, even if climate change is not a thing, I'm all down for investing into renewable energy and phase out fossil fuel even just for the cleaner air, the city where I'm from, Torino, is notorious for its air pollution. It would provide the opportunity to move away from centralised power grid too if you're worried about being controlled by a central body. Not-to-mention energy prosumer is already a thing.
author: Enzo MA

text:
I know that on climate change a lot of people seem to be divided along political lines, but that is irrelevant to me. I look at the facts, the data, and the practicality of moving away from fossil fuels. I agree that we need
to make the switch to renewables for all kinds of reasons. And from a practical POV I think nuclear will have to be part of the solution. However, I think the massive changes that some are pushing for in a short timeframe would be counterproductive. The actual data on many aspects of climate change does not match the alarmist rhetoric. And if you look at the many, very expensive studies and experiments that are ongoing, it is clear that the science is not settled. Cloud reflectivity is a prime example. It is the main cause of variations in climate models because how it will be affected by rising temperatures is not understood.

text: As someone who builds statistic forecast models for forecasting, and understands how important multiple sources of data, the slicing of data and the sample periods of data in all their raw forms are ... I am frustrated with many of the reports that the climate scientists base their findings on.  A lot of the data in their own reports, especially when you look at their on citations of data presented, are skewed by either cherry picking, narrowing sample periods, or failing to highlight margins of error.  An easy example of this are ground temps measured over time in areas that were rural and are now urban.  This is a skew of data, as the variables surround the thermal measuring instrument have changed and should be removed from the overall average.  A thermometer on grass is cooler than one on pavement on the same data, within the same mile.  When you start to dig deep into the data, you realize it his heavily flawed and is a very poor (if not false) statistical model.  This is why there is now this uprising.  For the record, I'm totally against pollution, especially industrial farming (especially salmon farming) and plastic.  But I cannot drink the cool aid on man's influence on global climate.  Local climate yes ie smog, but globally water vapour is the single biggest greenhouse gas which man, no matter how big his ego is, has no influence over.

text: ¬†@zalllon¬† Although you are right, the Earth's axial spin which causes the coriolis effect causes more water vapor to be concentrated in the equatorial region across Earth, we can control the carbon dioxide levels on earth, which means that we are able to have a significant impact on climate change. If you think my argument does not make sense, then consider the effect of global warming everywhere across the world besides the equator (Desertification, Higher frequency and intensity of storms, etc.). What you stated in your comment is not how scientists arrived at the consensus on global warming. No, you don't just put a thermometer at one location and observe its fluctuations over decades. Evidence from the gases trapped in ancient glaciers and ice showed that the usual carbon dioxide levels used to be only slightly above half of what it is now, 200 - 250 ppm, also you monitor the temperatures from a large variety of locations across the world, to obtain the general rising trend of temperatures. If you are lucky enough to be living in a location that has yet to see the vicious wraths of climate change, good for you, but never generalize your situation and think everything is fine and that nothing much changed.

author: Thatguys Son

text: ¬†@Thatguys Son¬† While you are right that green color (chlorophyll) in plants has a pretty high absorptance and low reflectivity (albedo) of a large spectrum of photon wavelengths (besides 500nm to 600nm which contains the green and yellow colors we perceive as shown in figure 5 of https://cnx.org/contents/-CmzvUct@11/The-Light-Dependent-Reactions-of-Photosynthesis ), it only accounts for a few milligrams of a millilitre of biomass as found in https://clu-in.org/download/ert/2030-R00.pdf. So what about the rest of the plant? (Summary of water cycle) Transpiration through the stomata of the leaves of plants cools it down a lot due to water's insanely high latent heat of vaporisation, which transfers loads of heat from plants to the atmosphere. The water vapor then reaches saturation point high up in the troposphere causing condensation which results in the formation of clouds and the vast amounts of energy lost to the surroundings during this stage causes negligible changes in temperature due to the sparseness of air near the tropopause. The radiation, however is released into space as water droplets have very very low transmissivity, so very low amounts of EM waves permeate through. Due to the fact that plants generally have very very high amounts of water (90-95% from https://science.howstuffworks.com/environmental/earth/geophysics/h2o5.htm ), and since it has extremely high specific heat capacity of 4180J/Kkg, it requires a huge amount of heat to heat it up. Water has high absorptance, yet the vast majority of radiation only results in negligible temperature increases and microwave radiation, despite being one of the best frequency to heat water, requires a huge amount of energy flux density, of up to 0.1 - 0.2 W/cm^2 for significant heat gain over a reasonable amount of time. Consider other factors,  and also ask yourself why is greenery described as a heat sink?

text: There's no such thing as man made global warming. Methane in the atmosphere is measured in parts per BILLION !  And it is volatile so it breaks down and doesn't accumulate. There is around 2 one millionths of methane in the atmosphere and most of that is naturally occurring. So if we exaggerated and said man caused half, that would be one part per million. Picture a pail with 1,000 marbles in it. Picture one thousand pails with one thousand marbles in each of them. Now take just one warm marble and add it to just one pail. Explain to me now how we just catastrophically overheated all one thousand pails containing a total of one million marbles. Saying that methane is a dangerous greenhouse gas is absolutely laughable and stupid. And CO2 is similar. Man has added only one twenty five thousandth in CO2 to the atmosphere since the beginning of the industrial revolution. See, they never tell you this. They mislead you to think it's a huge ratio, like 40% or something. Then they lie to you and say there is a consensus. That's bullshit. Less than 200 people made up that 97% claim. But there were over 31,500 fully accredited and vetted scientists that signed a document saying that man made global warming theory is bullshit. I wouldn't trust this James Hansen guy to make me a sandwich.

author: L Pappas

text:
L. Pappas
"It's this kind of logic that have people believing a rise in CO2 level is the only reason our planet would warm" - In the presence of a constant sun, a circular Earth orbit, and a constant angle of tilt, CO2 (and methane) ARE the only reason the planet warms.
Without the Milankovitch Cycle the natural Earth would cool slowly as mountain erosion and the photosynthesis of Life sequester the atmospheric CO2 until the Earth freezes to the Equator.  This freezing stops those processes, and it takes millions of years for naturally-emitted volcanic CO2 to top up the atmosphere until it becomes hot enough to melt the Snowball Earth.
The Earth has a Milankovitch Cycle which cyclically varies its insolation by the Sun, and interferes with its Snowball Cycle, producing greater and lesser ice ages as a consequence.
The Sun is stable and constant, for the purposes of this discussion.  Its output has very small cyclic variations to an almost-level slope of a very slowly rising output which will climax 4,500,000,000 years from now.
Even so, scientific papers have been produced since the sixties which show that the next Ice Age would have appeared at around 17,000 years in the future, not accounting for the atmospheric carbon dumped into the atmosphere by Man since the start of the Industrial Revolution.
Venus is warmer than it would otherwise be because of its massive CO2 atmosphere and also its massive sulphuric acid clouds.
If you would like to confirm this you need only read Hansen's publications where you can confirm his calculations.  These have been peer-reviewed, confirmed, so his claims have complete scientific backing.  They are true.
Follow your own advice and learn to think critically.
author: Tony Duncan

text:
¬†@Tony Duncan¬† I‚Äôm well aware of the Milankovitch cycle, but it appears you don‚Äôt know the variables within the cycle. Our orbit around the sun is not circular but varies from circular to elliptical, so our distance from the sun is not the same when we are in an elliptical orbit. 

Maunder minimum (Lack of sunspots) is considered to have caused the Little Ice Age which lasted from the 1300‚Äôs to around 1850.  This points to the sun not being constant in the amount of energy produced by the sun.  How much of the warming of the planet after 1850 was due to sunspot activity and how much was due to increasing CO2 and water vapor? 

Water vapor is a green house gas and makes up around 4% of the atmosphere.  CO2 is referred to as a trace element in the atmosphere because it makes up just 4/10‚Äôs of one percent of the atmosphere. You conclude the only reason for the planet warming is due to CO2 and methane.  

A few years back (2016) scientist had predicted the suns next 11-year solar cycle would start a cooling period. A Russian mathematician, Valentina Zharkova, studying the suns magnetic fields, has also predicted little sunspot activity for the next two solar cycles.  The year this new solar cycle was expected to begin was around 2018-2019. The winter of 2018-2019 has had early snowfall around the world and colder than normal temperatures from the previous few years.

text:
"We need to reduce CO2 emissions in order to reduce the intensification of the climate change effects such as global warming."
1) History has proven that co2 does NOT cause warming. At the very most it will add .5¬∞C per doubling of co2 WITH all the forcing factors.

2) Co2¬†was at historic low During the last glaciation. Had it decreased a tiny bit more, it would have caused the death of all life on this planet. It has been decreasing for millions of years as more and more of the carbon is stuck below ground and beneath the sea. Everything we add to the atmospheric co2 increases the lifespan of live on earth.

3) Increasing co2 increases the amount of plant food that the plants can create and thus the amount of animals, including humans that the planet can feed.

"The electricity has to be produced by carbon free energy sources like¬†... solar, wind " Despite what many people believe, solar and wind are NOT carbon free. Once they are created, they still have to have another source of power as backup since they are so unsteady. Nuclear has major problems with extremely dangerous risks. hydro and geo power plants are extremely site locational. The vast majority of the earth can not be feed by them.

A better way would be a gravity power, but for some reason no one is interested in using it. If it was really about getting cheap safe electricity why is no one looking at this?

"We need electric cars" In time the technology will replace I.C.E. engines, but forcing it will only harm the economy and ecology. Producing the batteries produces a lot of toxic materials and recycling them is both dangerous and very toxic as well.

There are new batteries that are likely to come out that are not as dangerous to people and the ecology, but they aren't here yet.

text:
¬†@Sean Slattery¬†  The oceans have been rising at the same rate for several thousand years from melting ice. That's what happens when the earth isn't frozen. The real big idiot statment that¬† in the past when the CO2 level was 390ppm the ocean levels were 15 meters (50' higher. The CO2 level is already higher than in the past. This is just one of the many other statments made that prove the AGW climate change theory is debubnked & climate change is natural. he earth has always had floods, storms, droughts & other events throughout history over various regions of the earth in different locations & different times. Secondly, Fun fact #1: ozone is a greenhouse gas. The ozone hole that was discovered in 1985 due to CFCs in Antarctica actually "not only reduced heat trapped over the region, it helped stir circumpolar winds, which in turn created sea spray that formed reflective, cooling clouds." from https://www.nationalgeographic.com/news/2010/5/100505-science-environment-ozone-hole-25-years/ so it caused an increased rate of warming in antarctica. 
Fun fact #2: UV rays are obviously carcinogenic. So technically letting an ozone hole expand and cover the entire world isnt a particularly good idea and the Montreal protocol at least prevented that environmental catastrophe where a ton of incident UV radiation hits Earth rather than being reflected off by the ozone layer.

text: CO2 is even produced and exhaled by all species of air breathing animals, including us. Plants take in CO2 and produce oxygen in a cycle that‚Äôs been going on for hundreds of millions of years. A healthy greenhouse effect has also helped keep the Earth warm enough to support different kinds of life. When dinosaurs roamed the Earth hundreds of millions of years ago, Antarctica was actually covered in forest. But since humans are now producing more CO2 than ever before, as well as other greenhouse gases like methane, the cycle is becoming more and more out of balance, and global temperatures are rising far more quickly than anything typical of the Earth‚Äôs natural climate cycles, like the ice age for example. (The ice age ended over the course of many millennia, but global warming has only really been going on for several decades and is already having a noticeable impact that will get exponentially worse.) The environment cannot adapt fast enough, and not even humans are equipped to defend against all the damage.

text:
Steve Spam Of course the Earth has been hotter than it is now in the last 500 million years. 500 million years ago, the first dinosaurs didn‚Äôt even exist yet. But in the past, the climate would usually change at a rate that was slow enough for species to adapt and survive. It‚Äôs one of the factors that caused evolution. But if the climate changes too quickly, it could lead to major disasters. One example that‚Äôs far more extreme than even what we‚Äôve been dealing with so far probably happened 66 million years ago, according to an article by National Geographic. A lot of people accept the possibility that the dinosaurs were killed by one of the many rocks floating in space, but most fictional depictions I‚Äôve seen show the impact, as if that‚Äôs what killed all the dinosaurs and somehow left the smaller animals untouched. In reality, if it really was a meteor impact, it was probably all of the ash and debris filling the sky and blocking out the sun that killed the big planets, starving the big herbivores, and indirectly starving the big carnivores. That ended once the ash settled, so the small creatures feasting on the corpses of giants survived and evolved into the animals we know today. All of that happened over the course of tens of millions of years, so to say that the Earth was hotter hundreds of millions of years ago doesn‚Äôt say much.


https://www.nationalgeographic.com/science/prehistoric-world/dinosaur-extinction/

text: ¬†@Darth Bane¬† These guys are largely persistent trolls. They love stating the % concentration of CO2 as a strawman and then argue how can a small number be so bad? But it's a meaningless ratio where you divide a non precipitous GHG by the sum of O2, Nitrogen, and a little bit of Argon, none of which are GHG's. You may just as well divide by the number of stars in the sky or grains of sand at the beach. It's pointless, but they love the number. Comparing CO2 concentration to H20 is also a red herring because H20 is precipitous, it reaches a saturation point and then falls as rain. CO2 is only removed by organic processes, dissolving in sea water (leading to acidification of the surface skin), and chemically through the weathering of rocks. An average ICE car that gets 20 miles per gallon of gas produces about 1 lb of CO2 per year, drive it 12,000 miles per year and you just put 6 tons of CO2 into the atmosphere, some of which will remain for hundreds of thousands of years (the chart has a very long flat tail, after the biosphere sinks and ocean sinks stabilize the remainder is consumed from weathering rocks, which takes a looooong time). H20 is an important GHG, but the relationship between CO2 and H20 is best described as CO2 as being the volume control, the more CO2 the warmer the air gets & the more moisture it can hold so the warmer it gets. These knuckleheads here don't care to learn, they just like to stir the pot. I like to kick sand in their face. I used to be polite until I realized the willful ignorance I was up against.

text:
Temperature profile of Cities/Towns: Growing Thermal islands and weather stations.
http://www.mdpi.com/2413-8851/1/1/3
https://www.gislounge.com/urban-heat-island-analysis/
As cities expand the Weather stations gets effected by the error known as Urban heat (well known to early scientists in the late 1800s). 
The Early scientists who were studying the weather, knew about these urban thermal islands and made sure that the early basic weather stations were upwind (with prevailing winds) in the rural areas from the cities. They also took note of wind direction at time of readings. Now if you map the locations of weather stations (and their relocations and other structures including hills etc with wind) and map the encroachment of Urban life around it over time. For example a bird nest attached to a weather station can effect the humidity and Temperature readings giving an offset in error. When occupied the heat rises and when teh reader go to the box the bird flies away. The heat is still been given off while the reader is reading. Also the humidity can be effected as it is evaporating from the bird nest, especially when it is been built. Also the Reader can effect very fine measurement reading by their very presence. Breading down or near the sensor can effect fine tune humidity readers. The heat from the body can cause the temperature reading to rise slightly. Care must be taken by the reader to be down wind of the instruments when taking reading, as a human being is a thermal island and a humidity island.

When you map the development/Economic status over time, you will noticed the rapid development in the 1960's onwards that corresponds with the rising heat. The 1980s drop in heat production with the economic depression. Same with the cooling with the latest great economic recession caused by government bail outs by taxing the people and cuts in spending stopping people from generating heat. Also Look at population growth in line with Thermal heat expenditure and the reduction of family size as people moved into a nuclear family homes and then the next stage, the separation of families (divorce) with Thermal expenditure.  If poor people had more money they burnt more fuel giving off heat. Poor people were often suffered from fuel poverty during economic recession/depressions, hence the lowering of temperature. Now map both together. Middle classes also reduce their heat footprint, which effect the weather stations.

text:
In Thomas Jefferson‚Äôs book, Note on the State of Virginia, he argued for the United States to be founded on an agrarian ideology. In the excerpt we read for class today, Jefferson called for an American economy built on agriculture and to ‚Äúlet the work-shops‚Äù remain in Europe‚Äù. He recognized the need for some domestic industry but believed the vast land of America could be utilized by farming. Alexander Hamilton‚Äôs views contradicted Jefferson‚Äôs and his views on manufacturing and industry prevailed; consequently, America has progressed into a state of manufacturing rather than an agrarian state. This trend has become increasingly evident over time. Today, less than 2% of Americans farm. ‚ÄúEven though everyone still eats, taking part in the practice of growing food has less direct influence on people‚Äôs lives than at any point in our history (Hagenstein et al 3). Thus, we see the prevailing view of Alexander Hamilton as having profound impacts on the American economy and the global environment.

Thomas Jefferson adamantly advocated for the founding of this country to be based on agrarian ideals. Agrarianism supports working on land in ways that can last due to its focus on the interconnectedness of life (Freyfogle xix). Agrarians are sustainable and understand that humans need the Earth, land, and animals for our very subsistence. In the agrarian mindset, the health of humans is dependent in the long run on the well being of the larger land community (Freyfogle xix). Clearly, agrarian views dissent greatly from the views of the majority of modern people, especially those living in urban or suburban settings in the United States. Agrarians ‚Äúbelieve that those who buy products are implicated morally in their production, just as those who discard waste items are morally involved in their final end‚Ä¶ Producers and sellers, too, are morally responsible for their work, and in ways the market cannot absolve or cleanse when their products are sold‚Äù. Of course, one cannot live in a place without altering it, however, agrarians are about harmonizing their relationship and effect on nature, not exploiting it. From these readings, I came to be constantly asking myself the same question, ‚ÄúIf Thomas Jefferson‚Äôs agrarian ideology prevailed, would we still be in the current state of environmental degradation we are currently in?

text:
Ice cores show that warming *sometimes* comes before increased CO2 levels, not always. It's also an important distinction that literally no scientist has ever said that ONLY CO2 causes warming. We already have a good idea what triggered the warming events, the Milankovitch Cycle, which then causes CO2 (among other things) to be released into the atmosphere which further increases warming. 

>The earth has been warming up for the past 12,000 years, and has been going through warming and cooling cycles fairly consistently for the last 12 million years!!!

Not even remotely relevant to whether or not we can influence our climate. That's a lot like saying that you can't water your lawn because rain is a thing.

Our crops will¬†fail because the large land areas dry out¬†with GAT at¬†16'c. Many species are stressed at 16'c. Corals will not survive, phytoplankton will crash. They are the base of the food chain and produce 50% of the Oxygen on earth. At 16'c trees and other plants will start to die off. They produce the other 50% of our Oxygen. Measurements already detect lower Oxygen levels both in the Ocean and our Atmosphere. At 18'c most of our natural habitat¬†fails to cope or adapt and a mass die off is inevitable. We cannot live without our habitat. That's where we get all our food and water. At 18'c shallow sea shelves full of Methane Hydrate dissolve, this causes further warming to 22-23'c. text:
¬†@smallbluemachine¬† During the day plants in bright light use photosynthesis to take in carbon dioxide and give off o2 and water vapour During dim light periods respiration and photosynthesis are relatively equal and no amount of gases are given off. The processes are equal. At night time respiration occurs when o2 is taken in and co2 is released.
But the gases released by vegetative and/or organic decomposition are co2, methane, nitrogen and hydrogen sulphide. So the decomposition of organic matter contributes to greenhouse effect in areas where denuding of forests or fields once farmed are not replaced with more vegetation.

text:
¬†@InSight¬†
sorry, I missed the word "full", as in "for a plant to make FULL use of the high co2 they need more water and nutrients".

I learned at uni all those years ago, that increased co2 means that plants don't need to open the stomata as much or as long and thus has a decrease in evaporation.  this is "water efficiency".  what I was trying to communicate (poorly) is "total water use".

Sure with high co2 water efficiency might be up, but to get the maximum benefit of the high co2 to grow more and faster, it will need more water so it's total water use will go up.

but as I found out recently, this increased water efficiency in high co2 is not so in all plants.  cotton seems to go the opposite way.  "unlike in many other species, in cotton, the relative growth enhancement by high CO2 is not higher under drying soil compared with wet soil.."  AB Samarakoon and RM Gifford.  

Australian Journal of Plant Physiology 23(1) 63 - 74.  Published: 1996

An of course, if the soil doesn't have enough N or P, then high co2 or water means nothing.

in the Ordovician period the co2 concentration was 3000ppm [7.5 times greater than today] the temperature was 17c 

in the Cambrian period the co2 concentration was 6000ppm [15 times greater than today] the temperature was 22c

text:
The adverse impact of rising CO2 concentrations on the protein levels in pollen may be playing a role in the global die-off of bee populations by undermining bee nutrition and reproductive success. 

Samuel Myers, a senior research scientist at Harvard‚Äôs School of Public Health, has published groundbreaking studies on how rising CO2 levels lower the nutritional quality of foods that we eat, like rice, wheat, and maize, which lose significant amounts of zinc, iron, and protein when grown under higher concentrations of CO2. Plant composition depends on a balance between air, soil, and water. As CO2, the source of carbon for plant growth, proliferates quickly in the atmosphere, soil nutrients ‚Äî such as nitrogen, iron, and magnesium ‚Äî remain the same. As a result, plants produce more carbohydrates, but dilute other nutrients.

text:
The equator of the sun spins faster than the poles of the sun, this causes it to wind itself up like a top. It periodically releases this pent up energy over time then returns to a more normal state. This causes both short term and long term changes in the amount of energy given off by the sun. To monitor solar radiation we put a satellite into orbit between Earth and the Sun called SOHO  You can look up information about SOHO here https://sohowww.nascom.nasa.gov
Because we monitor solar output constantly we know for certain that modern warming is not caused by the sun. While solar output has been declining recently, the temperature has continued to rise. However the sun is responsible for some warming trends in the past.

The Earth is pulled in its orbit by the other planets. They tug on it over time and slightly change its orbit. The Earth's orbit around the sun is not a perfect circle but an ellipse. This change in Earth's orbit causes energy from the sun to hit the planet in different ways over time. This change in how the Earth orbits the sun causes long term changes in Earth's climate. This is called the Millankovitch Cycle. You can read about MIlankovitch Cycles here https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milankovitch_cycles
When the sun heats up the oceans the oceans release carbon dioxide. This carbon dioxide causes a feedback loop where the temperature rises even higher than the Milankovitch Cycle would have alone. Most changes in the climate prior to humans were caused by either changes in solar radiation and the Milankovitch Cycle. Milankovitch Cycles are over long time periods of 22,000 to 400,000 years. We know for certain that the Milankovitch Cycle is not responsible for modern warming. It does not make abrupt changes in climate we have seen in the last 100 years. However Milankovitch Cyles are primarily responsible for changes in the climate in the past.

In addition the ocean is currently absorbing Carbon Dioxide despite the fact that it's warming. You can read about the ocean absorbing Carbon Dioxide here http://pmel.noaa.gov/co2/story/Ocean+Acidification
This has never happened in the entire Quaternary. The ocean has never, in the last 2.5 million years warmed and absorbed Carbon Dioxide at the same time. This is unnatural.
author: Kevin Slater

text:
Carbon Dioxide is a well understood Greenhouse Gas. Increasing Carbon Dioxide into the atmosphere will, with absolute certainty increase the temperature of the Earth, you can read about it here http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/Features/EnergyBalance/page7.php

Humans are adding an unprecedented amount of Carbon Dioxide into the atmosphere. We know the source of Carbon Dioxide by the isotope ratios. Carbon-13 is a stable isotope of Carbon. Plants do not absorb much Carbon-13 because it takes more energy for them to use. This means that plants have less Carbon-13 than the atmosphere. If we see the percentage of Carbon-13 in the atmosphere falling we know for certain that the source is plant material. Oil and coal are ancient plants we know for certain that burning coal and oil is the source of atmospheric Carbon Dioxide. You can read about it here https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/outreach/isotopes/stable.html

The source of the increased Carbon Dioxide in the atmosphere is not from volcanoes, it is not from the ocean, it is, with certainty, from burning fossil fuels. It will heat up the atmosphere and it's source is humans.

The source of CO2 is from industrialized places in the world as we know from here
http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=89117

Other points. Winter is warming faster than summer:
https://www.climate.gov/news-features/blogs/beyond-data/climate-change-rule-thumb-cold-things-warming-faster-warm-things
The arctic is warming faster than the rest of the world
http://www.earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=81214
And the troposphere is warming while the stratosphere is cooling
http://www.pnas.org/content/110/43/17235

These are what we call 'fingerprints' of human caused climate change.

text:
Becca Panarra There is an excellent solution. Not solar panels, I'm afraid. Nor "wind turbines". Electric energy cannot be stacked like cordwood or coal. The environmental resources needed to store it as hydro power can be computed as so many cubic metres at whatever 'head' - the difference in height between to upper pnd and the lower exit -- is available. Their aren't enough mountains and valleys that we can spare.
Nuclear power is the answer, ignore the lies of Amory Lovins, Helen Caldicott,  and Mark Z. Jacobson. 
Three weeks before the disgraceful Chernobyl meltdown, the only civilian one that killed anybody, the second Experimental Breeder Reactor of the IFR project was deliberately and successfully tested for its idiot-proof immunity to meltdown, and it had already proven that it could consume uranium 238, which is the long-lived 95% of so-called "nuclear waste", and the plutonium and other trans-uranics.
The USA has a total of less than 80 thousand tons of not-really-spent nuclear fuel, and less than 4% of that is fission products, which are decaying at rates of which the slowest takes 30 years for half the isotope to decay.
author: Albert Rogers

text:
"Electric energy cannot be stacked like cordwood or coal"
Your correct, it cannot. But don't underestimate how much less energy is needed if each house has solar panels, even in a country that spans the arctic circle like I live in you get a lot of electricity, in particular during the time when you got your AC running.

My point is just, don't dissuade from solar panels, talk about how to improve the effect of them. Btw, we have nuclear power here too, combined with lots of river power, wind and solar. Not a coal or petrol power plant to be seen. Our government is trying to get more and more incentives out so the population can, and wants, to install solar cells on roofs.

Diversifying the electricity profile is important to avoid sudden power outages.

"Their[sic] aren't enough mountains and valleys that we can spare"
Converting water into hydrogen to store electricity is a sane approach on some scales, houses and cars for instance. Proven safer than petrol (at least by the companies that are pioneering the cars and gas containers).

As a side benefit, releasing extra oxygen into the atmosphere would (at a drop of water in the ocean level) slightly reduce the green house effect by diluting the CO2 concentration.

author: Steve Smith

text: Why not? Do you have a more efficient suggestion?
author: Adam Leckius

text:
Sure. Much better at this stage in our technological advancement to increase carbon in our agricultural soils, (something we must do anyway) than eliminate fossil fuels (which will also need to be done, but needs some improvements in the renewables technology). Not to mention the fact that completely eliminating fossil fuel emissions to zero tomorrow will still result in decades to centuries of AGW anyway. It can't solve the problem alone. We still need to sequester the extra already in the atmosphere. But by far there is plenty of room in our highly degraded agricultural soils to hold every bit of the extra CO2 in the atmosphere and restore the balance.

So yeah, much more efficient to use well known technologies in agriculture that are even profitable, than to spend insanely vast amounts of money to eliminate cheap energy.
author: Red Baron Farm

text:
@Red Baron Farm - His solution is revenue neutral (making it viable in Congress) and market-based (making it efficient).

Fossil fuels are only cheap because of the $500 billion/year subsidy the world pays outside of the price of the fuels from the pollution, national security, health effects, accidents, ocean acidification and climate change they cause.  

Putting a fee on the fuels simply accounts for those negative costs to society, and makes fossil fuels compete on a more equal footing with other energy options.  Returning all the money collected (minus administration costs of a few percent a year) protects our purchasing power, and the economy.  

The Citizens' Climate Lobby proposal is to do this with a steadily increasing fee rather than all at once, so the market can do what you say and provide the solutions over time.  But the market needs the direction to do so, and something like the clear market signal that making Carbon Fee and Dividend a law is necessary to get us out of the current mess we're in.

text:
I will again attempt to clear this up. The Earth receives radiation from the sun,  over an area of about 127 million square kilometres facing the sun,, at about a watt or more per square metre. That's a Megawatt per sq. km. Suppose you have a greenhouse effect interfering with the outward radiation to the extent of capturing one thousandth of the power of the outgoing infrared. That's a thousandth of 127 million megawatts, which is 127 gigawatts of power. You may not notice a fraction of a degree in the air temperature, but consider the melting of ice, the warming of who knows what depth of water (it has been measured) and the melting of ice.
The carbon dioxide level in the atmosphere is definitely on a rising even if ragged curve. Among other things, that proves that it is NOT being turned into 'food'. The higher it gets, the greater the discrepancy between power incoming and outgoing.
It is called warming of the entire globe, which does NOT mean anything so tame as everything getting slightly warmer.

Statements like "The leading contributor of greenhouse gas emissions" completely and totally disregards how long those emissions exist in the atmosphere.
author: ErgoCogita

text: ergocogita ¬†how long does water vapor stay in the atmosphere?
author: Mandraquex3000

text: Water vapor exists as part of the hydrologic cycle. There is no hard set rate that it persists in the atmosphere but on average, it stays only 10 days until it precipitates out as rain. Once in the ocean, it can exist for several thousand years before evaporating.

Completely irrelevant, that's what.  Maybe you should learn what drives ice age cycles.  Milankovitch forces act on time scales of tens of thousands of years. text: Fourge Gaming It doesn't matter how intelligent, smart, or ignorant one is because regardless of any of that climate change will impact everyone in one way or another...sort of like how gravity pulls on everything with the same amount of force (even while in a plane). It wasn't that long ago that people thought flight and space travel were impossible but the science and technology advanced and we got to where we are now. The point isn't necessarily what you're trying to make it out to be. Yes science along with many things can have discrepancies but that doesn't negate the overwhelming majority truth of the facts. The point is the poorest/least well off of us in the world will be the first to feel and suffer the worst impacts... so whether or not your grandkids are smart or ignorant their skills of shooting, fishing, or whatever survival intelligence you believe will hold up against extreme natural disasters or drastic changes to the environment (which you clearly seem to enjoy) in the future are irrelevant and fall under a false sense of security because it will be hard to fish in a sea that is so warm the acidity level has killed the fish and it breeds the all too familiar flesh eating bacteria that has already become more and more of an issue/danger in many American fishing areas and killed quite a few fisherman already. Not to mention declining vegetation will throw off the natural balance of animals so that will ultimately become an issue for hunting if that is your fall back...so not quite sure how their survival intelligence helps there. Not only that but natural disasters of flooding and drought; pollution; dangerous bacteria; diseases; etc. these are all things that impact people equally whether they are intelligent or not. So if we know we can do things that are better for us all (even if you don't believe in climate change) in a less polluting/cleaner and more eco friendly way why not take that route instead of refusing to progress? If we had thought that way we wouldn't have airplanes, vaccines/medicines, automobiles, computers, boats, and even guns or the advanced and better quality of weapons that we all have the luxury of enjoying in our country. We all are responsible for our actions in life and the impact we have left behind will be our legacy. So while maybe you don't care or want to care and thus choose avoidance or denial so as to maintain your bubble of your world view is your choice and right but choosing to ignore a growing reality is like denying the air you breathe exists because you can't see it and refuse to acknowledge its very existence. It just doesn't make sense and seems rather selfish and one sided when there is so much knowledge and information out there to be learned and all it takes is trying to look at things from a different perspective/view outside of yourself.

author: Albert Rogers

text:
Emerset Farquharson I have to contradict the assertion "stable ...for the last 10k years". There is a gross instability recently introduced by humans, in taking out of the ground, and the atmosphere, the carbon, hydrocarbons, and oxygen that was separated and "sequestered" during the 60 million year Carboniferous period.
The resulting increase of CO2 can only be dealt with by vast amounts of regeneration of forests and other phototrophs.
But further increase can be slowed and stopped by replacing carbon combustion with nuclear fission.
In the whole world, since the invention of civilian reactors, there have been three nuclear meltdowns, of which exactly one caused a non-speculative number of deaths.
The USA has experimentally demonstrated two technologies that have idiot-proof immunity to breakdown. Russia has an 800 MWe reactor using fast neutrons, continuously breeding fissile fuel from common uranium 238, and even so inferior to the design that the Clinton administration abandoned.
The Sierra Club, Greenpeace, "Friends" of the Earth, and the NRC have  to answer for a great deal of failure to recognise this reality.
author: Albert Rogers

text:
Yeah Albert the recent instability has taken us out of the previous stable climate, I was mainly trying to get Nj to come out with more substance in his remark rather than resort to cliched platitudes about this topic.

About your remark on the only way to deal with the CO2 increase by reforestation, I don't think that's enough. I'm reading through the Assessment Reports from the IPCC about our state and where we are and where we're going and I'm not finished reading them but as far back as 1990 it was estimated that forests only account for reducing something like 30% of the extra CO2 we've added to the atmosphere. And ever since then the rainforests of Borneo have undergone a massive subsidised deforestation for logging and now for palm tree plantations for the cheapest vegetable oil in the international market. Protecting the Borneo forest and the Amazon and the remaining forests is extremely important but it's not enough.
author: Emerset Farquharson

text:
In the book by Matijs Beckers, "The Non-Solutions Project", there is mention of a scheme that might after all be quicker, if we had enough nuclear power. It has been shown experimentally on a very small scale that basaltic rocks have the ability to trap chemically, CO2 pumped down to them. Getting it out of the atmosphere is pretty damn' difficult, but there's another step. With heat, drive the carbon dioxide out of chalk or limestone calcium carbonate and into your mechanism to combine it chemically with underground rocks.
Now you've got quicklime, which you can directly add to the oceans (you might want to 'slake' it first) to reduce their acidity.

Obviously, all Greenland ice and most West Antarctic will be gone in 1,000 years for sure plus that big glacier in East Antarctic (it has as much ice as Greenland) with the rest of East Antarctic ice likely melting over the next couple of thousand years, but that's getting so far into the future that it's all up in there from then on.¬†

text:
http://climate.nasa.gov/faq/

"What‚Äôs NASA got to do with climate change?

When people think of NASA, they think of rovers on Mars, astronauts floating aboard the International Space Station, or probes veering out to the edge of the solar system. They don‚Äôt necessarily link NASA with climate research and observations. But Earth is a planet too, and NASA is one of the biggest players in the Earth science arena, with broad expertise on observing our climate, especially from the vantage point of space. Today it spends over a billion dollars a year doing Earth science and has more than a dozen satellites in orbit around the planet watching the oceans, land, ice, atmosphere and biosphere.
In the 1970s, NASA‚Äôs planetary exploration budget fell dramatically. It was then that the agency really got into the business of studying our home planet from orbit. It was also a time when people were beginning to realize that our climate could change relatively fast, on the scale of the human lifespan. Today, we know that our climate is changing at an unprecedented rate and that humans are a key part of that change. NASA continues to launch new satellite missions, and is also relying on aircraft (manned and unmanned), as well as scientists on the ground, to take vital measurements of things like snowpack and hurricanes, augmenting the big-picture view we get from space.

NASA‚Äôs role is to make observations of our climate that can be used by the public, policymakers and to support strategic decisions. Its job is to do rigorous science. However, the agency does not promote particular climate policies."

text:
Okay then, here we go, straight from the horses mouth

https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/monitoring-references/faq/global-warming.php

"The greenhouse effect is unquestionably real and helps to regulate the temperature of our planet. It is essential for life on Earth and is one of Earth's natural processes. It is the result of heat absorption by certain gases in the atmosphere (called greenhouse gases because they effectively 'trap' heat in the lower atmosphere) and re-radiation downward of some of that heat. Water vapor is the most abundant greenhouse gas, followed by carbon dioxide and other trace gases. Without a natural greenhouse effect, the temperature of the Earth would be about zero degrees F (-18¬∞C) instead of its present 57¬∞F (14¬∞C). So, the concern is not with the fact that we have a greenhouse effect, but whether human activities are leading to an enhancement of the greenhouse effect by the emission of greenhouse gases through fossil fuel combustion and deforestation."

https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/monitoring-references/faq/global-warming.php

"Global surface temperatures have increased about 0.74¬∞C (plus or minus 0.18¬∞C) since the late‚Äì19th century, and the linear trend for the past 50 years of 0.13¬∞C (plus or minus 0.03¬∞C) per decade is nearly twice that for the past 100 years."


https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/monitoring-references/faq/global-warming.php

"According to the range of possible forcing scenarios, and taking into account uncertainty in climate model performance, the IPCC projects a best estimate of global temperature increase of 1.8 - 4.0¬∞C with a possible range of 1.1 - 6.4¬∞C by 2100, depending on which emissions scenario is used. However, this global average will integrate widely varying regional responses, such as the likelihood that land areas will warm much faster than ocean temperatures, particularly those land areas in northern high latitudes (and mostly in the cold season). Additionally, it is very likely that heat waves and other hot extremes will increase."

"Are humans causing or contributing to global warming?

Yes, human activities have increased the abundance of heat-trapping gases in the atmosphere, which a large majority of climate scientists agree is the main reason for the 1.5¬∞F (0.85¬∞C) rise in average global temperature since 1880.[13,14] Carbon dioxide is the heat-trapping gas primarily responsible for the rise but methane, nitrous oxide, ozone, and various other very long-lived heat-trapping gases also contribute. Carbon dioxide is of greatest concern because its rate of increase is exerting a larger overall warming influence than all of those other gases combined, and because carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere will remain elevated for centuries unless we implement a way to remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere effectively and economically. Most carbon dioxide from human activities is released from burning coal and other fossil fuels. Other human activities, including deforestation, biomass burning, and cement production also produce carbon dioxide."

text:
http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/monitoring-references/faq/greenhouse-gases.php


"What are greenhouse gases?

Many chemical compounds present in Earth's atmosphere behave as 'greenhouse gases'. These are gases which allow direct sunlight (relative shortwave energy) to reach the Earth's surface unimpeded. As the shortwave energy (that in the visible and ultraviolet portion of the spectra) heats the surface, longer-wave (infrared) energy (heat) is reradiated to the atmosphere. Greenhouse gases absorb this energy, thereby allowing less heat to escape back to space, and 'trapping' it in the lower atmosphere. Many greenhouse gases occur naturally in the atmosphere, such as carbon dioxide, methane, water vapor, and nitrous oxide, while others are synthetic. Those that are man-made include the chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) and Perfluorocarbons (PFCs), as well as sulfur hexafluoride (SF6). Atmospheric concentrations of both the natural and man-made gases have been rising over the last few centuries due to the industrial revolution. As the global population has increased and our reliance on fossil fuels (such as coal, oil and natural gas) has been firmly solidified, so emissions of these gases have risen. While gases such as carbon dioxide occur naturally in the atmosphere, through our interference with the carbon cycle (through burning forest lands, or mining and burning coal), we artificially move carbon from solid storage to its gaseous state, thereby increasing atmospheric concentrations."

text:
¬†@Theminipwn¬† Boy I love idiots like yourself. You paid a fortune to sit ina¬†a classroom for years, only to be fed a diet of bullshit that you now consider to be on a par with Religion.

So lets put you back to bed.

Mars and Venus have the same concentrations of Co2.

Both planets have atmospheric CO2 concentrations around 95%. Earth‚Äôs atmosphere has only 0.04% CO2. The density of CO2 in both planet‚Äôs atmospheres is much higher than Earth‚Äôs atmosphere.
¬†
Temperatures on Venus average a balmy 467¬∞C, but temperatures on Mars average a nippy ‚àí63 ¬∞C. Why the big difference?
¬†

According to the ‚Äúrunaway CO2 greenhouse‚Äù theory, both planets should be really hot. Mars is twice as far away from the Sun, so its top of atmosphere receives only 25% of the solar radiation as Venus. But clouds on Venus reflect 75% of the sunlight ‚Äì so the SW radiation flux at the surface is similar on the two planets.
¬†
So why is Venus hot and Mars cold? Simple ‚Äì it is the atmospheric pressure.
¬†
The pressure on Venus is nearly one thousand times higher than on Mars. As the atmosphere convects, descending gases warm and ascending gases cool. The amount of warming is determined primarily by the increase in pressure.
¬†
Ever used a bicycle pump? Why does it get hot?
¬†
Answer : Because you are doing work to the gas when you compress it. Similarly, solar radiation transfers energy to the atmosphere, causing convection and heating of sinking air. If there was no Sun, the atmosphere would be very cold and would in fact freeze.
¬†
The runaway greenhouse theory makes little sense. If it were true, the Earth would experience it from water vapour, not CO2. H2O is a much stronger greenhouse gas than CO2, is much more abundant than CO2 and gets released from the oceans very easily and often ‚Äì particularly as the planet heats up.

The temperature chart is based on information acquired from NASA heat sensing satellites. It covers a 30 year period from January 1979 to November 2010The red curve indicates the average temperature throughout the entire Earth.

 The top of the curves are warmer years caused by El Ni√±o; giving out heat thus warming the Earth. The bottoms are usually La Ni√±a years which cool the Earth. Volcanic eruptions, like Mount Pinatubo in 1991 will also cool the Earth over short timeframes of 1-2 years.

text: The first-year ice that survived the summer, now defined as second-year ice, will thicken through autumn and winter. However, it would take several more cool years in a row to build the ice cover back to the state it was in during the 1980s, which consisted of a larger proportion of thicker, multiyear ice that was more resistant to melt. While ice in the Arctic will thicken through this autumn and winter, winds may also transport some of the thicker ice out of the Arctic and into the N Atlantic.
author: GravInducedSleepTrac

text: This year was notably different. Because this year‚Äôs wind pattern was different than 2012, the multiyear ice largely remained in a compact area along the Canadian Archipelago and did not circulate into the Beaufort and Chukchi seas. The cooler conditions this summer also helped preserve more of the first-year ice through the summer.
author: GravInducedSleepTrac

text:
Older, thicker ice remained in a region roughly between the North Pole and the Canadian Archipelago and the Greenland coast.

In recent summers, there has been considerable transport of older ice into the Beaufort and Chukchi seas, where it has been broken up and exposed to a warm ocean and high air temperatures. This has been a major factor in the loss of multiyear ice over the last decade.And
author: GravInducedSleepTrac

text: The pattern of ice thickness for the summer of 2013 is similar to what has been seen in recent years. According to data from the European Space Agency CryoSat-2 radar altimeter, the spring melt season started with an Arctic ice cover thinner than in any recent year. This corroborates thickness information inferred from a calculation of ice age that showed first-year ice, which is thinner and more vulnerable to melt, over a significant part of the Arctic Ocean as the melt season started. And
author: GravInducedSleepTrac

text: Over land, the cool spring resulted in greater than average March and April snow cover for the Northern Hemisphere. However, as in recent years, the snow melted rapidly, and by May, snow cover was at near record lows. Cooler weather conditions also limited surface melt on the Greenland Ice Sheet, which was still greater than the 1981 to 2010 average, but not near the record set in 2012. And
author: GravInducedSleepTrac

text: In contrast, this summer was characterized by unusually low pressure over much of the Arctic Ocean, which limited heat import from the south and brought more extensive cloud cover, keeping temperatures lower. In addition, the winds associated with the low pressure caused the ice cover to spread out and cover a larger area.
author: GravInducedSleepTrac

text: While 2012 and 2013 extents were similar through May, weather patterns from June to August helped retain more ice. Last summer was marked by lower than average pressure over the Eurasian side of the Arctic and higher than average pressure over Greenland. This resulted in a dipole-like wind pattern that favored ice transport across the ocean and the import of heat from southern latitudes along the Eurasian side of the Arctic. And
author: GravInducedSleepTrac

text: Contrasting weather conditions were a significant factor in this year‚Äôs higher sea ice extent and lower Greenland Ice Sheet melt intensity, compared to last year. This summer saw air temperatures at the 925 hPa level that were 1 to 3 degrees Celsius (2 to 5 degrees Fahrenheit) lower than last summer. It was also a cool summer compared to recent years over much of the Arctic Ocean, and even cooler than the 1981 to 2010 average in some regions, particularly north of Greenland. And

Of course it does. Combining satellite data at a different resolution than other data sets is no different from combining two data sets from any other two sensor systems at varying resolution; e.g. combining data sets from a 5 min. point data pyranometer and an hour sampling wide field spectrometer....

text:
The surface of Venus is hotter for three reasons (none associated with CO2 "greenhouse" warming):
1) The CO2 rich atmosphere creates a surface pressure more than 90X greater than on Earth
2) The slow, retrograde rotation of Venus produces "days" that last 243 Earth days. That is, more than an entire Venus year (one orbit around the Sun)
3) The lack of plate tectonics to dissipate core energy leads to long-term mantle warming culminating in a relatively abrupt "re-surfacing" event.

text:
ERBE
The radiation budget represents the balance between incoming energy from the Sun and outgoing thermal (longwave) and reflected (shortwave) energy from the Earth.
In the 1970's, NASA recognized the importance of improving our understanding of ERB and its effects on the Earth's climate.
Langley Research Center was charged with developing a new generation of instrumentation to make accurate regional and global measurements of the components of the radiation budget.
science. larc.nasa.gov/erbe/

The British study used climate-model simulations to examine the global hydrological cycle between the 1950s and 1980s. It found increased atmospheric aerosols were linked to a weakening global water cycle.
Precipitation isn't increasing as we had been predicting,'' Steven Siems, from Monash University's weather and climate group, said.
''But this [study] has included the effect of aerosols in the models and all of a sudden precipitation predictions behave better.''
Cont....
author: Bernie Zelvis

text:
Professor Siems said as the Earth warmed, more vapour could be held in the air. It meant there was more moisture available to fall as rain when a storm developed.
The research, which was published in the journal Nature Climate Change, was said to take better account of the impact of aerosols on the water cycle than previous weather studies.
NASA's ERBE helps scientists better understand how clouds and aerosols, as well as some chemical compounds in the atmosphere affect Earth's climate.

The El Nino weather pattern that can bring drought to Australia and rain to South America was ‚Äúunusually active‚Äù at the end of the 20th century, possibly due to climate change, a University of Hawaii study found.
El Nino-Southern Oscillation phenomenon has been increasingly active in recent decades relative to the past seven centuries.

NASA's ERBE measures directly the incoming and out going radiation of earth.
By doing this they measure the earths radiation budget which should total zero if it is in equilibrium.
It is not in equilibrium therefore energy is being retained.
This means global warming continues unabated and may show up in air temperatures or ocean temperatures or ice melting or other phenomenon.
Over 90% of that energy goes into the ocean hence El-nino & other ocean cycles create large natural variations.
author: Bernie Zelvis

text:
ERBE has helped scientists world-wide better understand how clouds and aerosols, as well as some chemical compounds in the atmosphere (so-called "greenhouse" gases), affect the Earth's daily and long-term weather (the Earth's "climate").
	In addition, the ERBE data has helped scientists better understand something as simple as how the amount of energy emitted by the Earth varies from day to night. These diurnal changes are also very important aspects of our daily weather and climate.

text:
Well, long before we measured the impact of CO2 on global temps we could calculate it:
The radiative forcing capacity (RF) is the amount of energy per unit area, per unit time, absorbed by the greenhouse gas, that would otherwise be lost to space. It can be expressed by the formula:
RF=100‚àën-1Absi*Fi/(pathlength*density)
i represents an interval of 10 inv cm. Absi the integrated IR absorbance, and Fi the RF for that interval.
It is a mathematical certainty incrCO2= incrTemp
Exactly as measured!

author: Bernie Zelvis

text:
"Another clueless, uneducated has mentioned "carbon fee""

A carbon fee is a tax on fossil fuels based on their carbon content, which is proportional to the amount of CO2 they will produce when burned.  It's done that way because it's a lot easier to measure what comes out of the ground or is imported, than it is to measure the amount of CO2 emitted from each smokestack and tailpipe.  The fee can go to taxpayers in an equal per-capita green check.  Some prefer that some go to deficit reduction.

author: Peter5930

text: The solar irradiance at Venus is 2613.9W/m^2, while the solar irradiance at Mercury is 9126.6W/m^2; 3.5x the irradiance at Venus.  Despite getting 3.5x more sunlight, Mercury is only 0.46x as hot as Venus.  That's the difference a strong greenhouse effect makes.  Mercury, with no greenhouse effect, is less than half as hot as Venus, with a strong greenhouse effect, despite Mercury getting 3.5x more sunlight than Venus.
author: Peter5930

Venuses distance from the sun is 109,000,000km, mean surface temp is 735 K; the average surface temperature of Venus is hotter than the hottest part of the hottest day on Mercury. text: @sdrawkcabgnipytmi That is not what I was just doing. There is a fixed relationship between temperature and radiational intensity that is specified by the Stefan-Boltzmann law. I merely used that law to show how the IPCC's equation implied an amplification of the hypothesised radiative-input to the climate-system. Yes the law applies specifically to black bodies, but it can be generalised to cover grey bodies when combined with the coefficient of emissivity/absorptivity of the body in question.

However, it must be remembered that the ice sheet expended down almost to Mexico 14,500 years ago, and has been melting ever since. Also, the Sun is entering a less-active phase which will cool Earth in the next decades. Get your sweater
author: Randall Hawes

text:
@bweazel The jet stream is caused by the differential heating of the earths surface and the rotation of the earth and its position is chaotic in the short term.

Dont be thinking such movements have anything to do with AGW, they dont. Also dont be thinking that localised weather is representative of global climate, it isnt.
author: LiamE69

text:
@bweazel It certainly is complex, but in other ways it is simple. If the earth receives more energy than it radiates it will warm. CO2 slows the rate at which we radiate energy, so the more there is in the atmosphere the more the earth will warm.

Tipping points and so on can add huge complexity to that simple equation, but its underlying truth remains.
author: LiamE69

text:
@bweazel Its not so easy to predict a large complex system without having been through the exact same conditions before. We know there are tipping points, but we will only know with hindsight exactly where they were.

Scaremonger is largely the reserve of media. Scientists stick to what they can show and give ranges. Media just about always runs a story on the upper bounds of possibilities a study shows with the tag "scientists say"

text: N2, O2, and Ar don't differentially absorb radiation: shortwave (solar) and longwave (terrestrial) are absorbed and emitted equally. CO2, on the other hand, doesn't absorb shortwave radiation much but absorbs lots of longwave. That means over 99% of the atmosphere isn't causing any warming, it's only the little concentrations like 390 parts per million of CO2. Small concentration, large effect.
